This spoiler-free guide will help you learn to love the game and help you progress when you may feel lost or frustrated.

This game is so incredibly unique that I didn't like it for the first half of my playthrough because I didn't understand HOW to enjoy the game. But once it clicks, you get hooked and you don't want to put the game down because you suddenly pieced something together and you know how to progress.

WARNING: Basic game mechanic spoilers ahead (i.e. mechanics you learn within the first couple hours of playing; the ship log, for example)

So for people who are stuck or confused on how to progress or aren't really hooked in your playthrough yet, here are some tips that will help you learn HOW to enjoy the game and may help you progress:

Tip 0: Use gamepad/controller, not KBM. It's much easier to control your ship and there's also one specific section in Dark Bramble where having a controller will be very convenient.

Tip 1: Your ship log (particularly Rumor Mode) is crucial to the overall experience in this game. It guides you towards what your next objective could be (you don't have to do most of it linearly). Locations marked with a "?" means you haven't fully discovered everything in that area, or you haven't actually been to/in that location. If you're stuck, look through those locations on your ship log and pick a place you want to try to get to.

The ship log notes key details that you should remember from the Nomai dialogue you translate. These will provide you with clues on where to go or what to do to progress. They give you multiple different hints and the fun part about the game is looking at all your clues and piecing the puzzle together on what to do next. This combined with the next tip makes you feel like the most intelligent person in the universe every time you figure out what to do.

Tip 2: Learn the time loop and embrace the time loop. Understand how your solar system works and the differences between the beginning, middle, and end of the time loop. Learn the characteristics of each planet. What is changing throughout the loop? Study them, analyze them. You can also "doze off" at any of the campfires in the solar system to pass time quickly.

Now that you understand the mechanics of each planet, think about how the hints provided to you via the ship log may interact with these mechanics. Be in certain places at certain times. It's a lot easier to do trial-and-error with the next tip.

Tip 3: There is a secret dialogue option that provides you with an extra quality-of-life feature. I will mark sections of this as spoilers rather than the whole thing, so you can reveal small hints one-by-one rather than the entire thing if you want.

The feature: [spoiler]In the pause menu,[/spoiler] [spoiler]you'll unlock an option to[/spoiler] [spoiler]"meditate until next loop", which is essentially just a "restart loop" button.[/spoiler]

How to obtain this: [spoiler]You have to have talked to[/spoiler] [spoiler]Gabbro (on Giant's Deep) in a previous time loop[/spoiler] [spoiler]then come back to him on or after the 3rd loop.[/spoiler] [spoiler]Ask him "How do you stay so calm in the face of repeated impending death?" to unlock this feature.[/spoiler]

Tip 4: USE YOUR EQUIPMENT!!! This is the biggest thing I neglected but it's there for a reason. Your Scout Launcher and your Signal Scope are key features that you will need to progress. I got stuck once because I thought they were just "gimmick" features. No, you are required to use them to progress in some areas.

Tip 5: If you find an "unknown frequency" with your Signal Scope, make sure you get close to the source with your Signal Scope out and it will register it with a name on your Signal Scope. So if you ever need to go back to it in the future, it's labeled for you.

Tip 6: When in "landing mode" in your ship or when you're wearing your spacesuit on any planet, you can see a little globe on the left of your HUD. Red is the north pole and blue is the south pole. This will be helpful later in the game. Remember this by thinking of a compass and how the red arrow always points north.

Tip 7: If you're confused about a specific puzzle or you just don't really understand how to progress in one specific area on your ship log, don't be afraid to just save it for later and go try to solve something else. Many times, you're unable to progress without having specific knowledge from a different branch of the log.

Tip 8: If you're repeatedly trying something and it's still not working, you're doing something wrong.

Tip 9: If you're REALLY really stuck, take a step back and think about all the information you know about something. For example:

- This [planet] has a hidden area I cannot currently access
- This [same planet] has [this specific mechanic] that changes it throughout the time loop
- My ship log told me [these hints] about this planet

Now try to combine all that information and apply logic to the clues.

Tip 10: If you've done the above and still have no idea how to progress, r/OuterWilds on Reddit has a ton of spoiler-free hints on how to progress. Just look up where you're stuck followed by "reddit" and you'll find plenty of spoiler-free responses that will guide you in the right direction without outright telling you what to do. Obviously do this at your own risk though, but I never had a spoiler when I had to look things up.

I will say, it's so much more satisfying to figure it out on your own, but there are some puzzles that are extremely difficult and seemingly obscure (they're not obscure when you have all the clues). So try to spend some time figuring it out on your own before giving up. You really have to think outside of the box for some of the puzzles. Especially for the last puzzle of the game to get to the A[spoiler]sh[/spoiler] T[spoiler]win[/spoiler] [spoiler]Project[/spoiler].

------------------

Overall, brilliant and incredible game that will test your detective skills and out-of-the box thinking. I have never played a game that was this unique in my life, so I'd highly recommend! The OST is peak also, so if anything, you have to play it for that. | before this, games were starting to get boring for me and i missed that feeling of genuinley enjoying a game i have been very lucky to stumble upon this game and even if i havent finished the game yet while still i love the game.this game is a great story game but just one tip dont be going on youtube or anything to spoil the ending thats how good it is.the game has puzzles mysteries exploration and much more.just give it a chance and see what happens | [h2]Eine knisternde Wundertüte für echte [i]Entdecker[/i][/h2]
Diese Review wird frustrierend vage. Denn Outer Wilds lebt vom Reiz des Unbekannten, der intrinsischen Neugier. Entsprechend weiß man am besten nicht zu viel, bevor man sich auf die Reise in dieses faszinierende Sonnensystem macht. 
Aber ein paar Dinge sind doch wichtig, denn obwohl Outer Wilds ein hervorragendes Spiel ist - es ist auch ziemlich speziell. Deshalb folgt hier ein kleines quasi spoilerfreies Briefing, bevor ihr die Triebwerke zum ersten Mal startet.

[b]Die Situation[/b]
Es ist ein großer Tag für unseren Spielcharakter. Nicht nur werden wir nach abgeschlossener Pilotenausbildung heute das erste Mal ins All fliegen. Wir haben auch ein mobiles Übersetzungsgerät dabei, das unser Volk gerade frisch fertig entwickelt hat. Damit sollen wir die überall im Sonnensystem verteilten Inschriften entziffern können, die eine vermutlich längst ausgestorbene Alienrasse dort hinterlassen hat. 

Lasst euch nicht vom gemächlichen Intro auf dem Heimatplaneten irritieren, ihr werdet schon noch lange genug durchs All zischen. Und dort dann völlige Freiheit genießen. Keiner sagt euch, was ihr euch zuerst anschauen solltet - lasst euch einfach von eurer Neugier treiben.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3381247382
Ein bisschen Orientierung kann das Logbuch verleihen, das euch sagt, wenn ihr an einem besuchten Ort noch nicht alles entdeckt habt. Außerdem gibt es dort eine Übersicht aller eurer Erkundungen, wobei Zusammenhänge wie bei einem Kriminalfall mit Pfeilen verbunden sind.
Trotzdem werdet ihr wahrscheinlich an den Punkt kommen, alle Planeten einmal bereist zu haben und ein bisschen auf dem Schlauch zu stehen, wie es wohl weitergeht. Doch ihr solltet nicht verzagen. Outer Wilds gelingt abseits weniger Schnitzer eine fast unsichtbare und dennoch verblüffend gute Spielerführung. Irgendwie habe ich nach etwas Herumprobieren doch fast immer etwas Neues herausgefunden - oft begleitet von einem wunderbaren "Aha"-Moment.

Diese Momente waren für mich die absoluten Highlights des Spiels. Die Mysterien und Eigenheiten dieses Sonnensystems sind so dermaßen kreativ und erwecken ein Entdeckergefühl sondergleichen, wenn wir sie in ehrfürchtigem Staunen Stück für Stück begreifen.

[b]Was zu beachten wäre[/b]
Dabei sind die Rätsel sehr organisch in die Spielwelt eingebunden - im Grunde sind die Planeten selbst und die Gesetze nach denen sie funktionieren die eigentlichen Rätsel. Zum Lösen kann unsere übersichtliche Anzahl an Tools nötig sein. Oft müssen wir aber auch einfach "nur" zur richtigen Zeit am richtigen Ort sein. Timing ist nämlich alles in Outer Wilds. Das Universum entwickelt sich in seiner beeindruckenden Simulation stetig weiter - bis... Ja, findet es selbst heraus. Verpassen wir den rechten Moment haben wir jedenfalls genug andere Gelegenheiten, es nochmal zu probieren.

Manchmal kann Outer Wilds dann auch etwas langatmig und repetitiv werden, wenn wir bei einem Mysterium einfach nicht mehr weiter wissen. In besonders extremen Fällen sollte man sich meiner Meinung nach nicht dafür schämen, mal kurz in einen Guide zu spicken. Die von einem wunderbar einprägsamen, Banjo-lastigen Soundtrack untermalte Atmosphäre des Spiels ist nämlich echt toll. Wäre ja schade, wenn man sich die verhagelt, weil man mit seinen stetig verzweifelter werdenden Lösungsversuchen konstant auf Granit beißt.

Für die Rätsel auch sehr hilfreich und für das Begreifen der Geschichte sogar unumgänglich ist ein gesunder Lesehunger. Wir finden auf unserer Reise haufenweise Inschrift-Tafeln der erwähnten alten Alienrasse. Die behalten immer kleine, gut geschriebene Geschichten - auch wenn sich ihr Informationsgehalt aufgrund der nicht-linearen Natur des Spiels manchmal doppelt. Diese Text-Happen sind gut verdaulich, summieren sich aber. Wer sich so gar nicht für das Lesen in Spielen begeistern kann, für den wird sich Outer Wilds wahrscheinlich stellenweise zäh anfühlen.

Es lohnt sich aber, hier dran zu bleiben. Wir entwickeln trotz den Texten als ((einzige)) Verbindung eine enge Beziehung zu der Alienrasse, lernen wie und warum diese ganzen Bauwerke im Sonnensystem entstanden sind oder über die großen Ziele dieses hochentwickelten Volks.

Eine letzte Anmerkung: Ich war erst verunsichert, weil das Spiel ziemlich prominent das Gamepad als Eingabeoption empfiehlt. Maus und Tastatur gehen aber auch völlig klar, wie ich dann feststellte.

[i]Persönliches Rating:[/i] [b]85[/b]/100

[i]Fazit[/i]
[h3]Outer Wilds belohnt engagierte, entdeckungsfreudige Spieler mit einem sich immer in Bewegung befindlichen Sonnensystem voller faszinierender Phänomene und Geheimnissen, die uns die Ehrfurcht vor dem Universum ins Gesicht zaubern![/h3] | [h1] Un juego que trasciende el tiempo y el espacio [/h1]

Seguro has visto otras reseñas que describen a [i]Outer Wilds[/i] como un juego que se puede jugar únicamente una vez, pero ¿qué tiene de especial para generar ese sentimiento en tanta gente?

Una de las principales razones, y lo que lo hace tan diferente a otros juegos, es que [i]Outer Wilds[/i]  no se trata de completar niveles, hacer a tu personaje más fuerte ni conseguir nuevos ítems. El progreso lo logras como lo harías en la vida real: con conocimiento y experiencia.

[h3] ¿Cómo es el gameplay? [/h3]

En [i]Outer Wilds[/i] eres un astronauta que explora un pequeño sistema solar, mientras un bucle temporal reinicia el universo cada 22 minutos. Durante ese tiempo, se desencadenan eventos que alteran elementos clave en los diferentes planetas que puedes visitar. Sin embargo, la razón detrás de este bucle es un misterio para ti, solo sabes que está relacionado con una civilización alienígena desaparecida, cuyas ruinas y textos antiguos están esparcidos por todo el sistema solar.

Tu astronave cuenta con una computadora que guarda información clave y te ayuda a seguirle la pista a los principales rumores de los planetas que visitas. Mientras más conocimiento recopiles, más secretos se irán revelando. Conectarás los puntos en tu mente y podrás resolver el misterio poco a poco, al mismo tiempo que te vuelves cada vez más hábil en pilotar tu nave y volar con tu propulsor.

[h3] La primera regla de [i]Outer Wilds[/i]: No hables de [i]Outer Wilds[/i] [/h3]

Como seguro ya lo has deducido, este juego se disfruta al máximo comenzando a jugarlo con la menor cantidad de información posible. Incluso el mínimo spoiler podría arruinarte un puzzle o un secreto. Pero quédate tranquilo: todos los acertijos del juego pueden resolverse únicamente con la información que el propio juego te proporciona.

Si te sientes atascado, no te preocupes, ve a otro planeta, explora un poco más. Los planetas están diseñados para que puedas identificar puntos de interés mientras vuelas en tu astronave, [b]deja que tu curiosidad te guíe[/b].

[h3] Lo que nos cautiva de este juego [/h3]

[i]Outer Wilds[/i] es un juego como ningún otro, simple en sus mecánicas, pero que logra crear una experiencia completa. Sus misterios te atraparán y despertarán tu curiosidad, especialmente si disfrutas indagar en el lore de los juegos. Al desentrañar cada parte del rompecabezas descubrirás las formas ingeniosas en las que el juego oculta sus secretos a plena vista.

A lo largo de tu travesía, conocerás a un puñado de personajes que, de alguna manera, estarán contigo en cada paso. Es este contraste entre la inmensidad del cosmos y la cercanía de estos encuentros lo que hace que [i]Outer Wilds[/i] deje una huella permanente en quienes lo experimentan.

vale cada centavo, e o fator replay nem se fala... tantas builds pra experimentar, tantas quests, tantas ideias, apenas 50/80 horas de elden ring não vai te passar a vibe real do jogo kkk, mas compre. vale cada centavo. desde a história do jogo que é muito completa e imersiva, ambientação (que foi criada pelos anjos, meu Deus, que design de cenário maravilhoso), as trilhas sonoras que te enchem de tensão, medo ou paz e conforto, as mecânicas de combate que se encaixam como luva, sempre te levando a criar uma nova estratégia (já que aqui você não vai sair descendo a porrada em todo bicho kkk aqui existe balanceamento, e de acordo com tua progressão, os inimigos também ficam mais fortes), em suma, o jogo é incrivel. 

e se tu nunca jogou um game da from software antes, comece por aqui. acredito que elden ring seja mais fácil que dark souls 1, 2 e 3, no quesito de ser muito explicativo e fácil de pegar o jeito, até o parry é mais fácil. (pelo menos pra mim, que ja joguei os três e tive essa visão)

e como costumo dizer... gostar de jogos soulslike é uma referência a vida real, você vai apanhar até aprender, mas quando aprender, vai ser prazeroso cada momento. 

aproveitem :)

*ler mensagem:* contemple... o anel pristino! | 엘든 링이라는 게임 말이죠. 제가 이 게임을 하면서 느낀 건, 이건 그냥 게임이 아니라 제 삶 그 자체라는 겁니다. 야구하면서 힘들었던 시절이 떠오르더라고요. 트리가드라는 첫 보스를 보자마자, 이거야말로 저를 시험하는 신의 장난 같았어요. 처음에는 딱 보자마자 “아, 이 정도는 껌이지”라고 생각했죠. 그런데 아니더라고요. 던지자마자 맞고, 굴렀는데도 맞고, 그러다 결국 다섯 시간을 죽도록 싸우고 나서야 겨우 이겼습니다. 그때 느낀 감정이 뭐였냐면요. “아, 이건 그냥 내 영혼이 싸운 거다.”

야구로 따지면 2회에 갑작스럽게 마운드에 올라가서 볼넷 던지고 나서, 코치님이 올라와서 “긴장하지 마라, 편하게 던져라”라고 했던 순간이 떠올랐어요. 그때처럼, 이 게임도 포기하지 않고 계속 던지다 보니 공이 포수 글러브에 쏙쏙 들어가듯, 보스의 패턴이 보이기 시작하더라고요. 결국 직구처럼 강하게 한 방 날리고, 트리가드를 쓰러뜨렸습니다. 이게 뭐랄까요, 그 짜릿함은 그냥 표현할 방법이 없습니다.

그리고 이 게임의 오픈월드는 말이죠, 제가 처음 미국으로 가서 야구장에서 길을 잃었던 그때를 떠올리게 했습니다. 길을 걷다 보면 갑자기 동굴이 나타나고, 그 안에는 무시무시한 보스가 기다리고 있어요. 그런데 그걸 깨고 나면 이상한 아이템이 나오고, 그게 또 나중에 엄청난 역할을 하더라고요. 야구로 따지면, 마이너리그에서 그 힘들었던 날들이 나중에 메이저리그에서 자신감을 주는 것과 같았어요. 그 과정 하나하나가 소중한 추억이 되고, 나를 단단하게 만들어주는 거죠.

스토리도 참 난해하더라고요. NPC들이 무슨 말을 하는데, 딱 제 영어 초창기 시절 생각났어요. 감독님한테 “Hey, how are you?” 한 마디 하려고도 얼마나 연습했는지 몰라요. 근데 그 어색한 대화 속에서, 오히려 진짜 나를 찾게 되는 느낌이 있었습니다. 이 게임도 마찬가지예요. 이 세상이 왜 이렇게 망가졌는지, 내가 왜 싸워야 하는지 고민하다 보면, “아, 이건 그냥 내 이야기구나” 싶더라고요.

결론적으로 엘든 링은 그냥 게임이 아닙니다. 이건 우리 삶 그 자체입니다. 어려운 상황에서 넘어지고 다시 일어서고, 그러면서 성장하는 그 과정이야말로 우리가 왜 도전하고, 왜 살아가는지를 보여주는 것 같아요. 제가 은퇴 후에도 팬들 덕분에 새로운 길을 걸을 수 있었던 것처럼, 이 게임도 플레이어에게 새로운 길을 열어주는 힘을 가진 것 같아요. | FYI- I finished the main game then I posted this review there is a lot of side content left

not as difficult as others make it out to be, people act like this game is super hard 100% of the time but while it can challenging this game gives you a lot of room to explore and level your character so anytime you feel like a boss is too hard you can just go explore or do one of the many side quests available and then return once your strong enough.

Call of Juarez has really great story telling and voice acting, and decent duck and cover gameplay. Mostly is it really cool game, but there are enough quirky mechanics that could hamper your experience.  The style has elements of genius that is worth playing if you can pick this up for a few dollars as it can be completed once in 10-15 hours. 

Your character narrates his role in the wild west and explains his tall tale version of what "really" happened during key events of US old West history.  It has a great comic book like style to introduce classic outlaws in an epic fashion, and the world is bright and beautiful with romanticized farmhouses, mine shafts, moving trains, and mountains.  The levels are mini areas that allow you to run within a defined arena as you hide behind structures and gun sling your way past groups of outlaws as the narrated story offers entertaining, color commentary to all the events. 

The game felt more like a shooting gallery style on rails rather than stealth strategy.  I mostly liked the ducking for cover and the shooting since your character can take some bullets yet quickly recover if you stay out of the next wave of attacks. You can pick up just a few basic pistols, rifles and shotguns to keep it interesting, and also upgrade a few power ups that allow you to carry more bullets, or to throw back incoming dynamite.  The gameplay also has an interesting dueling mode for some of the bosses where you need to increase focus meters, and out draw the enemy.  The historical nuggets that you can find on each level add a side study of the many outlaws who become the stories of the 1800's United States.  It is a great combination of tall tale and non-fiction.

As the game went on, the difficulty suddenly would ramp up and the quirks of the game became more apparent.  The enemies blend into the background making them super hard to see, yet they would easily spot you behind any barrier.  The voices of the enemies seem to come from all around and sound like they are right next to you, even when they are 50 yards away. The Q "Concentration" button helps to slow down the action and to outline your enemies but for me it would burn out so fast before I could do much. I was disappointed in the perk system as I used my points on the Silver Shotgun, Ranger Gun, and the Ornate Sawed off since they seemed like the best weapons, although as the game progressed it seemed like the regular Rifle was important to reach far enemies, and the standard Quick shooter was better for rushing enemies.   The game has a few quick events that popped up at very random times and most likely will surprise you and kill you.  When you die, sometimes the game has a tendency to place you immediately in mortal danger only to die again on the same group of enemies.  I kept dying over and over chasing a dynamite fuse that blew up in 5 sec, and I could not even see what direction I was even supposed to go.  Some of the bosses had glitches or quirks and I do not understand how I passed them besides getting a little lucky.  
For the boss Henry Plummer, I could not figure out why enemies were hitting me when I should have been safe behind a barrier. Yet somehow after many, many tries, I lucked out and he suddenly died, and I can only guess that I blew up the dynamite in his hand.   For the boss Curly Bill, he got stuck while running in place in the lumber yard so I just kept shooting him until he died.  For the boss, John Wesley Hardin, I could not figure out what the game needed me to do in the dueling event as I would draw, dodge, but the aim target would wander off. Eventually after many tries, somehow the target worked but I did not feel satisfaction that I did anything differently.

There is a lot to be loved about the style of this game, which is why I recommend playing it despite the quirks.  There is more gameplay with NewGame+ and Dueling Mode  and it may spark your curiosity to learn a bit some of the outlaws during a crazy era of US history. | [h2]🎨 Graphics [/h2]

Reviews:
I used to play this. A lot, as you can see from the playtime. Most of the time I spent in the game was in 2022-23. I had a good group of people I played with and the servers were full of great people. We didn't really know what we were getting into, however, and eventually we all started playing less and less. Mostly because we realized that this isn't really a game. It's a job that you can pay your employer for the privilege of playing. You either pay to skip the grind or you perform ridiculous amounts of fetch quests and spam the 'G' (interact) key. I'm not kidding when I'm saying there are things that you need to do hundreds to thousands and tens of thousand times. There is an 'island soul' that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a pouch that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a mob. I don't know what the math on that works out to exactly, but googling says in the thousands of hours.

Gear 'honing' has abysmal success rates and you lose materials on every attempt. The honing materials are tiered and each level requires a different material so all your old mats are virtually worthless when you move up a tier. Drop rates for 'collection' items are extremely low and many mobs, bosses, events, and/or islands only spawn once or twice a day/week, so collection can take hundreds of hours for a single item.

Every system in the game is designed to take as much time as possible, every single day, unless you pay. Even if you pay, the time gates and drop rates stay the same, so you still have to grind. Beyond the currency bloat, there are also 4+ XP systems you need to grind.

I stopped eventually because of the sheer grindiness and utterly ridiculous currency and loot box mechanics. I came back recently because I heard some of the newer updates reduced the grind and simplified the currency. I thought I'd take a look and see whether it was worth coming back to.

I should not have. The grind is all still there and, if anything, is worse. The currency has been simplified a bit but it is still ridiculous. There is still silver, gold, crystals, royal crystals, pirate coins, open seas coins, pheons, shards, fragments, and probably others that I've just forgotten. There are six different 'profession' currencies that you have to collect and each of them has multi tiered rarities. You can convert between all of these at awful (like 10 to 1) exchange rates. There are sinks for all of them everywhere.

Despite simplifying some things, they've added whole new systems to make things even more grindy and confusing. These systems have new fetch and farm quests and use different materials that you need to use that have low drop and conversion rates. It's just more of the same.

Trying to play content from before the endgame is hit or miss because people are simply not there and the content is not accessible by just one person. You can ask in chat and you might get lucky, but there is very little incentive for an end-game character to help out with content that they probably haven't touched in years. There is a 'solo' mode option for some pre-endgame content, which can be useful, but it's a little laughable having a 'solo' mode anything in an MMO.

I could try to find a guild and try out discord to get some older, wider content done, but that doesn't solve the grind and loot box issues this game has. I don't mind grinding for an item, but grinding for just a chance at an item is a special level of hell.

There are some nice people still playing and you might be able to connect with them in game or over discord and get some things done if you are new or returning, but if you value your time, money, and sanity, don't. Pick another MMO. | Quiero aclarar que el juego en si es muy bueno, el problema es que no recomendaría este juego a un jugador nuevo, ya que solo puedes jugar a este juego y disfrutarlo siendo nuevo jugador si tienes amigos que ya jueguen de antes y tengan personajes muy avanzados. Los jugadores nuevos son muy fácilmente identificables, siendo muy difícil que te inviten a grupos para poder realizar el contenido final del juego. Por otro lado, es un juego extremadamente exigente respecto a las horas necesarias dedicadas al día, por lo tanto, es necesaria una inversión de horas extremadamente elevada para que puedas jugar de manera autónoma, pudiendo ser frustrante para muchos jugadores nuevos. | This game suffers a major struggle as one that is developed by a Korean development company and published by an American company who pushes the game updates from KR to the western version of the game. The publisher has no power or will to transform the new (or current) player experience in a meaningful, permanent way that will help them ascend to the relative power levels of veteran players.

One of the best examples: Gearing a character in this game requires collections of 'cards' for card sets which are a huge component of damage or support power for players. As such, it requires too much time commitment and/or money for new players to get to a point where they are comfortably playing endgame content with veteran players or normal consistent raid lobbies at all due to this huge missing chunk of damage or support power.

Due to the nature of raid leaders being able to inspect the full range of gear for applicants to raid lobbies, many players will be rejected because of their lack in raid power. Due to the difficulty and dps checks of some raids, the lower power players will have a hard time clearing raid content with each other at all even if they do make their own lobbies.

The developers did make content called 'solo raids' which can be completed for some of the relevant gear materials, but due to the content release schedule of the game, players are never quite able to catch up because their rate of growth is too slow.

By the time a newer player is ready to play a newer raid, most of the population will have moved on to a newer raid, and a fresh player will not have an easy time finding a raid group in the Lobby Finder that will help them learn an older raid. The older raids are referred to as 'homework', and players are often expected to already have played and farmed the raid enough by that time, so as not to hold back the players who want to complete this 'homework' raid for their needed gold.

Speaking of gold, the Western version of the game is suffering from very high economic inflation due to the rampant and seemingly unstoppable plague of gold farming bots. Korea doesn't suffer from this issue because their game client requires a Korean SSN to verify identity. Steam has no such requirements, so bot accounts can be made in mass volumes to this day.
It's against the terms of service for players to purchase gold from these bots, but they continue to do so and purchase (from the Auction House) either large volumes of honing materials or high value gear which also happens to be in high demand from the general population.

Lost Ark at its core was such a cool game and I'm happy to have played it since launch, but as of Feb2025 it's not hard to see that this game's publisher (Amazon Game Studios) and/or developers (Smilegate) continue to betray its audience at large by not acknowledging core issues at all or addressing them in a timely manner.

There are other issues I'm sure I forgot to mention, but needless to say I can't recommend this game for any new or current players at this time. | i love the game, but management is  the worst you can get in MMO.

[h1]Сначала человек изобрёл шахматы. Затем человек изобрёл дробовик, чтобы в этих шахматах можно было выиграть.[/h1]

Великолепное переосмысление самой переоценённой игры в истории, отправляется в список моих любимых рогаликов. Я в шоке от глубины проработки и как из такого простого концепта можно выжать столько игровых механик, которые генерируют столько неожиданных геймплейных ситуаций. Потенциал билдов более чем раскрыт, тащить можно чем угодно. Меты как таковой нету, бóльшая часть перков так или иначе полезная, так что всё в ваших руках и на высоких рангах майндгейм зашкаливает. Справедливости ради, чаще всего вас банально будут зажимать фигуры, потому что ходят они по несколько штук за один ход. Да сложно, да рандом душит порой, но тем не менее затягивает. Дал поиграть деду, он кончил. А у него уже лет 30 не стоит... Говорит о многом.

Из минусов хотел бы отметить дизбаланс прогрессии а также невозможность пропуска выбора. Тобишь, чёрные карты почти всегда уступают белым и ты регулярно обязан выбирать между двумя плохими наборами. Имбовые чёрные карты тоже есть, но на мой взгляд маловато элементарных стат-апов на фоне полутора десятка белых карт, которые откровенно руинят забег если ты их подбираешь. Чего только стоят Таймер, Хилящие офицеры, Стреляющие короли и Кошмарные Кони. Ну или игра наролит кучу фигур на доске и вдруг оказывается что оружие ниxepa не способно вынести прущий навстречу легион. Особенно это всё ощущается на высоких рангах, которые надо проходить молитвами нaxyй. 

[code]Стоит отметить, что игра довольно короткая и забег в среднем проходит за 7-15 минут, так что слив не столь фрустрирует как в каких-нибудь комплексных рогаликах, где по полчаса трайхардить приходится.[/code] 

Учитывая что игру относительно часто обновляют, жду когда добавят больше карт на урон, патроны и уменьшение разброса. И почините наконец эту хрень когда убиваешь фигуру позади которой стояла другая и тебя ваншотит перманентно. Что самое интересное, если убить преграждающую фигуру гранатой то ваншот не прокнет, но я вам этого не говорил... | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | It was a great fun game with levels that get a little bit harder, and you can get different shotguns and after each round you pick a card that upgrades your side, and the enemy. The normal amount of turns in a round is maybe 20-30, and 9 rounds in the level and i think 8 levels. There is also endless and chase.
 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.
No Reviews

Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
Reviews:
方舟一直都是我心目中的生存游戏天花板，21年用着一台很破烂的手机接触方舟虽然只有是十几帧，但是很快乐，22年放暑假的时候用着姐姐核显笔记本玩，直接卡到爆炸闪退，但是体验到手游与端游的差距后，立志要买一台不卡电脑开最高画质玩，23年放暑假用自己凑了很久的钱在咸鱼上买二手零件组装了一台R5 5500cpu,显卡RX590玩，但还是很卡，低画质六十帧都没有，于是我开始慢慢节约开销，一点点省下来，25年1月份我用这些钱买了一台搭载I7 14650hx和4070显卡的笔记本，我开着最高画质玩，我完成了我儿时的心愿，没有遗憾，现在是我人生中最快乐的时候，不说了，方舟生存启动！ | 作为沙盒生存史上最伟大游戏之一的ARK，只能说喜欢的人玩几千个小时都不腻，玩不进去的基本很早就退坑了，其原因无非就是不喜欢恐龙元素或者是游戏难度问题，这款游戏给我个人的感觉就是前期坐牢，中期最好玩，后期爽，大后期就会非常腻，一般这种时候就该换地图了，或者是玩点别的游戏缓解一下，等过段时间再继续体验会更合适，本人1000小时+，大多数时间都是自己单机，偶尔多人联机，人多其实才更好玩，当然这也得分情况，pvp很容易让人红温是真事，但是比起单机更不容易玩腻，可操作性会多很多，pve会玩的更舒服一些，在此极力推荐刚入坑或者会坑的新人们先去单机玩孤岛（island）这张初始地图熟悉一下各类操作和恐龙，即时是玩最简单的这张地图，新手前期也是最难度过的时候，坚持下来了你就是下一位大佬，撑不住那我还是劝你换别的游戏，玩游戏还是开心最重要，没必要折磨自己，但是我当初前期的时候也非常享受，因为我觉得探索新事物是最有趣的，现在的我已经逐渐套路化，感觉再也没有当初一开始的那种感觉了，虽然说我不会退坑，但是基本上也没啥新的体验了，还是祝各位玩家玩的痛快吧，痛苦并快乐着，不说了继续刷材料 | This game is not perfect by any means. Programming wise, not particularly well omtimized. Bugs still happen, creatures do weird stuff etc. With that in mind, I fucking love this game. I have met so many great people and communities with this. Been with it since before breeding was a thing. I've had laughs, cries, love and heartbreak. And all the dinosaurs. All the adventures. The long nights fooling around in this world. Many hours, such worth, very good. Absolutely worth it. | Очень интересно и ни**я не понятно))) Но мне всё нравится, прекрасные пейзажи, огромный мир, полная свобода действий. Отличная механика приручения и разведения животины. | ---{Gráficos}---

Game Name: ARK: The Survival Of The Fittest
Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Strategy
Reviews:
It's criminal that this game is still being sold, considering that the servers are seemingly permanently down. | [h1] ARK: The Survival of the Fittest – мёртворождённый эксперимент [/h1]

Когда разработчики ARK: Survival Evolved решили вписаться в жанр королевских битв, казалось, что идея неплохая: битвы с динозаврами, приручение прямо в бою, выживание против других игроков – всё это могло бы стать чем-то уникальным. Но реальность оказалась печальнее.

[h2] ✅ Что в игре хорошего: [/h2]
✔ В теории – интересная концепция (если закрыть глаза на исполнение).
✔ Динозавры в королевской битве – звучит круто, но только звучит.

[h2] ❌ Почему в это никто не играет: [/h2]
✖ Мёртвая с момента выхода – онлайн просто нет, даже боты бы не стали заходить в эту игру.
✖ Кривой баланс – если ты не оседлал Т-Рекса в первые минуты, то готовься стать кормом для тех, кто успел.
✖ Отвратительная оптимизация – просадки FPS, лаги, баги, как будто движок и сам не хочет, чтобы эта игра существовала.
✖ Никому не нужна – на фоне других королевских битв вроде PUBG, Apex Legends или даже фанатских серверов в оригинальном ARK эта игра просто не имеет смысла.

Это не просто провал – это игра, которая умерла ещё до того, как кто-то всерьёз в неё поверил разработчик. С таким же успехом можно попробовать сыграть в PUBG на выключенном мониторе – хотя бы нервы целее будут.

2 из 10 покинутых серверов. | ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is the ultimate test of survival where it’s not just about fighting dinosaurs—it’s about surviving in a world where everything, from the weather to the creatures to your fellow players, is out to get you. Picture this: you’re dropped into an island with nothing but your wits, some rocks, and a stick, and you’ve got to figure out how to stay alive while dodging massive carnivores and attempting to avoid becoming someone else’s dinner. Add in some players who think they’re the island’s top predator (spoiler: they’re not), and suddenly, your quest to survive turns into an all-out, hilarious game of “who can mess with who first?” Trust me, it’s intense, but also surprisingly fun when you realize you’re a second away from being eaten by a T-Rex and you somehow make it out alive. That’s when the real fun begins!

At its heart, ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a battle royale-style game set in a prehistoric world, filled with dangers both natural and player-made. The basic premise? You, along with other players, are dropped onto a hostile island where you must gather resources, craft weapons, tame dinosaurs, and try to survive long enough to become the last one standing. The twist? You’ll need to strategize, team up, or even betray others to outsmart and outlast the competition. It’s not just about surviving the creatures; it’s about surviving the players too. Tame some raptors, build traps, create defenses, and get ready for combat because the last survivor on the island wins. Oh, and don’t forget about the giant mutant spiders and those terrifying, unkillable bosses roaming around. In short, everything wants you dead, and you have to be smarter, stronger, and faster to avoid becoming dinner.

What really stands out about ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is the blend of survival mechanics, strategy, and chaotic multiplayer action. The vast array of creatures you can tame and use in combat adds layers of complexity to the gameplay. The game rewards strategic thinking, from deciding when to team up with others (and when to stab them in the back) to figuring out the best way to hunt or avoid the island’s mega-predators. The crafting system is deep, and the thrill of gathering materials to build your base and weapons while fending off enemy tribes is incredibly satisfying. If you’re into survival games with a high stakes, high tension environment where every decision counts—and where a single mistake could lead to an epic failure—ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a must-try. It’s perfect for anyone who loves a challenge, epic dino battles, and the thrill of outlasting other players in a hostile environment. Trust me, it’s chaos—and it’s absolutely worth diving into! | sera que volverán los servidores alguna vez??? | Игра просто бомба от слова совсем! Я скачал ее в 4 время уже 9 до сих пор не могу оторваться. Только жалко то что играет не особо много людей человек 10 а так имба! Всем советую. Если у вас кучу времени и нервов то эта игра вам подойдет.

Unfortunately due to game being abandoned It's not worth buying at full price, wait for a massive discount. Get's rather boring after the first couple of months... same thing. | Идея более-менее хорошая, но это очередная стратегия, где можно взять мясо, атаковать и победить, где можно победить числом. Самый большой минус в том, что игра ужасно плохо оптимизирована 2/10 | BU oyun yerine total war'dan rastgele bir oyun alın daha iyi. Total war oynayan birisi olarak adamların total war'a özendiğini söyleyebilirim. Bari 3D modellerini iyi yapsalarmış. | 一款方向性比较强的RTS，应该说这游戏的游戏性因为要还原一战所以让步给了真实性，导致这游戏的总体评价不怎么样。
总之步兵在各种防御工事以及坦克的火力之下显得非常脆弱，无论是进攻还是防御你坦克数量不够的话前半场基本上都是蹲在战壕里等敌人步兵冲击以及等双方炮兵进行友好交流。这游戏最好玩的时候是在刚开始玩的那几个小时里，等你把步兵、炮兵、飞机、坦克、毒气弹、固定工事这些东西全部玩个遍，新鲜感过去后就会逐渐感觉无聊。我觉得后期感觉这游戏无聊的最大原因在于这游戏本身的机制，你想要占领某个地区就需要把这个地区的星星全部打掉，而消掉一颗星需要你取得一次大获全胜，也就是要么对方主动投降，要么你把对面指挥部占了(在进攻战中通常这没啥区别)。也就是说你费劲儿操作半天打赢了才只能消掉一颗星，而每个地区至少都有两颗星，部分重要地区更是有着三星四星，而且如果你不持续攻击这个地区，只要停火一回合这个地区就会恢复一颗星，基本上是在强迫你不停操作持续进攻。最终导致你费劲打了四十多分钟，才把战线往前推了一点点。防守战也是，兵力和对面差距不大的情况下自动战斗基本上都是僵持或小败，虽然不会扣你的星，但是要扣你的钱和国民意志，反正就是要你选择，是图省事扣钱和国民意志自动战斗还是亲自微操耗你一大把时间。然后在这无尽烂仗的背后，就是你打了半天发现战线和最初没什么太大的区别。
在前期的新奇感过去之后，你面对的就是无穷无尽的烂仗，无穷无尽的重复地图，无穷无尽的蹲坑对射，无穷无尽的来回调兵，和基本上没啥变化的战线。某种意义上非常还原一战民众的心情，从刚开战时大家踌躇满志逐渐被无休止的战争折磨到希望这场战争早日结束。
总的来说买来玩玩还可以，体验赛博一战，在致敬历史这方面感觉制作组还是用心了的，但是你要是抱着买个正经RTS来玩的想法的话我觉得还是算了这游戏不太行。 | [h1] Tarihi Derinlik, Yavan Bir Deneyim [/h1]
Birinci Dünya Savaşı’nın stratejik yönlerini derinlemesine ele almayı hedefleyen bir oyun olarak büyük umut vaat ediyordu. Ancak ne yazık ki, vaat edilen derinlik, sıkıcı ve tekrarlayan oynanışın gölgesinde kalıyor.

Öncelikle, oyunun temposu inanılmaz derecede yavaş. Siper savaşlarının doğası gereği savaşların uzun sürmesi anlaşılır bir durum, ancak buradaki savaşlar bazen gereksiz derecede uzuyor ve sıkıcı hale geliyor. Sürekli aynı taktikleri uygulamak, ilerlemek yerine yıpratma savaşına girmek ve her çatışmanın birbirine benzemesi oyunu monoton bir hale getiriyor.

Yapay zekâ oldukça basit ve tahmin edilebilir. Düşman saldırıları genellikle aynı şablona dayanıyor, bu da her savaşın birbirine benzemesine yol açıyor. Diplomasi, teknoloji ve stratejik derinlik açısından da büyük eksiklikler var. Oyunun sunduğu karar mekanizmaları yüzeysel kalıyor ve uzun vadede oynanışı etkileyen büyük değişimler yaşanmıyor.

Görsellik ve arayüz de bekleneni tam anlamıyla veremiyor. Savaş alanları detay açısından oldukça zayıf ve çoğu zaman birbirinden ayırt edilemez durumda. Ses ve atmosfer olarak da oyuncuyu içine çekmekte zorlanan bir yapım var, özellikle savaşın kaotik havasını yansıtan güçlü bir ses tasarımı eksik.

Sonuç olarak, The Great War: Western Front, ilgi çekici bir tarihi dönemi işleyen ama bunu yeterince etkileyici bir şekilde sunamayan bir oyun. Eğer gerçekten detaylı ve taktiksel bir savaş deneyimi arıyorsanız, bu oyun sizi kısa sürede sıkabilir.

it's a fun, well rounded golf game that will definitely see improvements in the next game.  this game runs well and doesn't take itself too seriously.  i have had a blast playing with my friends online and in the MyCareer mode. | Le jeu est globalement intéressant à la base avec des parcours globalement agréables. Dommage qu'il y ait des lacunes pour certains parcours plus que mythiques (on peut penser à St Andrews, et plus largement aux parcours européens).  
Mention spéciale pour la création de parcours qui, bien qu'avec un éditeur largement perfectible reste une initiative particulièrement intéressantes. 
Cependant, un gros point noir vient ternir le jouabilité : la gestion de la difficulté est difficile à calibrer et même parfois aberrante. Une fois pris un peu en main, la difficulté est régulièrement mise à mal et on se à jouer des parties très faciles et à dominer trop largement. Ou alors à devoir réadapter régulièrement la difficulté du parcours. Petit détail, même avec un mode de difficulté maîtrisé par le joueur, le jeu peut passer en mode "plus rien ne rentre" : un même écart au coup parfait sera tout d'un coup bien plus pénalisé que précédemment, à bonus équivalents.
Encore cela pourrait relever de l'aléatoire et resterait acceptable s'il n'y avait pas ce dernier point : des parties sont parfois ridiculement difficiles. Par exemple, en finale de fedex cup, certains trous sont à peu près injouables, c'est à dire qu'il n'existe qu'un m2 sur lequel poser sa balle sur le green pour qu'elle n'en ressorte pas (franchement, je n'exagère même pas). Et vous pouvez partir avec le plus gros avantage possible avec les points fedex (plus du double de points par rapport au second vous procurera deux coups d'avance... pas très réaliste, mais soit), il est quasi impossible de finir les trous en question sans faire un score de 10. Encore une fois, en étant normalement dans un mode par ailleurs maîtrisé par le joueur. Cela rend le jeu plus que punitif et induit une mauvaise frustration. 
Vraiment dommage. | It's not 2003-2009 but it sure is fun while you're cooped up indoors during the winter! Some people say the career is a little shallow, and it can be, but compared to EA its all really about the same general idea. I just like that I can play golf and pretend I'm working toward the PGA. The graphics aren't stand-out amazing, but at least its not polygons and sprites, the faces and animations could be better, the grass and water could look more real, but the physics really aren't bad, and it feels good to play 18 somewhere so , 7.5/10 for me. | Good interface for mouse use, Good graphics, | Gameplay is fun, but I cannot recommend games that do not support Steam Cloud. Nothing is more frustrating than finding out that all your progress is gone....

Genres: Action, Adventure, RPG, Simulation, Strategy, Free To Play
Reviews: Its a fun game especially with friends

Обалденная игра! Пока играешь приходит расслабление, а за ним и мысли о вечном, пока соединяешь дома. Шикарно! Рекомендую. | Good game,

gets a little bit repetetive after an hour I would say, but it was definitely worth playing.

The game mechanics reminded me a little bit of Tetris but different. The goal is to combine small buildings to create even bigger buildings that can house more population (in this case the population is simply the score and has no other effect). You can see the next 4 buildings coming up - similar to the next block appearing in Tetris. However you are not under any time pressure, so you can plan ahead peacefully.

There are a few interesting twists by combining several buildings in a single turn which award you cards if you've done enough of them. In return those cards give you strong moves that would be otherwise impossible such as switching building positions for example. Without them your progress would be much more limited.

我认为我去选择玩这个种族就是想体验这个种族独特的科技与魔法，而不是换皮肤体验重复的大家共享的魔法池。但不管是最近要出的文明还是这个游戏都把这些体验拆分开来，文明可选，外观可选，科技和魔法都可选，看似更自由了，但想看另一个魔法另一个种族的特性的这种新开存档的激情却减少了，总而言之就是没意思了，没有独特的种族游玩流程那还有什么意思呢？ | The Game itself is a very good tactical turn based game. First off, since the last big update, the game has a tendency to crash on the campaign map. Which is really annoying, but dealbreaker for me is, that it also corrupts saves, so you cannot continue where it crashed. Especially annoying when you just fought a big battle and then lose all your progress.

Second is, that yes - you can create different civs - but in the end, they all play very similar. You always want to rush your city cap and just build as many armies as possible. Build wide, claim as much territory as possible. That's the strategy. The only difference is how your units look and what tomes you unlock. To be fair, some of the final tomes are very unique, but it takes a very long time till you get there and most of the game is already over by that point.

Third, the campaign map itself. You notice it is randomly generated. It's a combination of biomes with some features in it and some randomly placed ancient wonders. Every map looks similar. Sometimes it has more forest and sometimes more sand, but in the end, there are no "unique" landmarks or sights. After a few games, you have seen everything. Which would be okay, but one of the key points of this game is to go out and explore the map... which is just not interesting.

This game is a lot like Rogue Tower, if rogue tower didn't suck. The balance needs some work but if they can work that out this is a helluva cool game. If you've played Rogue Tower you'll like this better.

Gameplay
Standard Tower defence with a twist, you pick a tower and a gem. The tower determines what the tower does, the gem determines all of the important characteristics. Any gem can go into any tower, but not all gems work well in all towers. The Rain tower for example doesn't work well with gems that only deal damage as it applies the full DOT but only does a tiny amount of damage. Once you've got towers set up you'll have to equip your towers or you won't make it far. What you get to equip them with is entirely up to RNG. 

Towers
There are six towers and six gems. 
There is also a Bomb, all you need to know about the bomb is that there is not, at time of writing, a pause button.

The Towers - All stats  vary wildly based on the gem in the tower, important information will be listed
Boulder - Lowest fire rate, highest damage, small AOE on impact, Low DPS, great tower for things that do things every X seconds. 
Firethrower - Moderate fire rate, moderate damage, Directed AOE hits all units in path, DPS suffers from the fact that this tower tracks enemies rather than firing in a set direction. 
Projectile - Highest Fire rate, moderate damage, good single target DPS. 
Lightning - Low fire rate, short range, less damage than the projectile tower, hits several targets within range for moderate damage
Rain - low damage, low fire rate, low range, creates a persistent AOE that deals damage to all units in an area
Spike Tower - Low fire rate, moderate damage, mid size AOE on impact, 
Bomb - There is no pause button
At level 10 each tower gets an upgrade, each tower levels up individually.

Gems
Arcane - Highest Fire rate, second lowest damage. Fire rate scales 20% better than normal, damage scales 10% worse.
Upgrades: Fire rate, crit damage, healing per wave, gold per wave, item generation, AOE per kill and a temporary fire rate buff per kill. 
Fire - Lowest damage, second highest fire rate, burn DOT. DOTs are 20% more effective, 10% less damage to slowed enemies.
Upgrades: DOT, dealing extra damage on the final burn tick, damage, enemy healing debuff, permanent burn increase per kill, increased burn on crits, gold generation per burn tick, and instant burn application once burn hits 1000.
Earth - Lowest fire rate, highest damage. 20% extra damage to armoured enemies, fire rate scales 20% worse than normal
Upgrades: Range, stunning crits damage to armoured enemies, stacking damage buff per wave, reduced crystal cost, stacking damage during combat buff, AOE bleed on kill, AOE on kill.
Poison - Moderate fire rate, moderate damage, Poison DOT. 5% increased damage per second in combat (up to 50) 15% reduced damage to burning enemies.
Upgrades: Damage to poisoned enemies, poison damage, tower exp on kill, poison spread on enemy death, inc poison on armoured enemies, AOE on kill.
Electric - High crit chance. 40% increased critical damage scaling, 10% reduced damage to armoured enemies.
Upgrades: Chance to double damage, chance to ignore armour, stacking crit damage boost per kill, crit damage, boost to damage fire rate and DOT (as a single upgrade), chance for gold/crit, AOE on kill, Chance for additional chain
Cold - Moderate damage, moderate fire rate, slow. Increased damage to slowed enemies, 50% reduced DOT.
Upgrades: Increased slow, increased damage to slowed enemies, crit chance, AOE on kill, freeze chance, Tower EXP per wave, chance for additional hits gold per kill. 

Issues
Balance
Ostensibly you need to use a variety of towers to achieve a win. In practice you max out the ice progression tree, spam projectile towers with ice gems and then just keep playing the next wave. Why? Because projectile towers offer the best DPS and ice gems gain experience every round which gets them to level 20 very quickly. Why does that matter? Two reasons, one levelling up makes your towers better, and two at level 20 your towers give all other towers of the same type an additional equipment slot (up to 20 slots total) and this lets you put in as many items as you'd like. On top of all of that it slows enemies.

Other
You can't remove towers once you've placed them. 

Conclusion
Overall I like this game and reccomend it if you like tower defence games. | If you are like me and love both Tower Defense and Roguelikes this is a must get. They combine the features of both genre perfectly. None of the elements are to deep yet intertwine well so you see progress each run. 

As a TD alone it is a fun game. Add in the roguelike elements and the fun doubles. | huge potential, developer still working on the updates, cant wait for more

上手之后会立马显得重复度略高，而且局外成长太花时间，要体验到完整的内容很费劲。

其次在上强度之后，游戏会从模拟建设瞬间转化成微操资源管理，人力和资源的极致运用才能让你拿下胜利，你说肉鸽？什么肉鸽？哪有肉鸽？建设？哪有建设？

这不算充足的随机性除了能让你升血压并不能让你的体验得到提升，毕竟这个游戏所有的肉鸽收益基本都是有滞后性的，鲜少有立即生效却对你收益巨大的情况出现，游戏本身也是比起解决问题更倾向于让问题防患于未然，可以说基本都处于一种今日受苦而明日享福的循环，而人往往并不待见延迟满足，这也是城市建造类游戏的通病，随机性则让这一点被增幅了许多，毕竟脸黑一下的话你的精心布局很可能要到游戏尾声才得以找到key牌启动。

在真正上手游戏的中后期，本作特色的“肉鸽”“建设”属性可以说是基本等于没有（甚至肉鸽方面可能是负作用？），冲着这两点来的颇有几分受骗的味道。高强度下的资源匮乏和时间赛跑让游戏的建设属性约等于无，时间全花在拼尽全力管理有效利用资源上，而肉鸽属性正反馈不足，且低难度通解太多、高难度拿不到最优解血压又太高，负反馈很强导致肉鸽的设计很抽象。

相对的，游戏耐玩、结构与内容完整，微创新也不少，上手简单易懂，游戏内有明确的阶段性目标，能让城建玩的少的玩家不至于迷失方向不知道该做什么，每一局的目标不一样一定程度上保持了新鲜感都是值得肯定的优点。

总的来说是值得一个好评的，入手推荐史低，另DLC风评远不如本体，慎入。 | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | 与其说是城市营造或者基地建设，更像是有限资源管理游戏，不符合我的兴趣

I think Terra Invicta is a perfect example of the all-too-common case of a game that simply tries to do too much.  The majority of successful games fall into at least one of three categories:

1.  Simple yet robust mechanics and artistic direction.
2.  Broad public appeal with serviceable game-play.
3.  In-depth simulations and a targeted niche market.

Terra Invicta is closest to the third, and yet seems to misunderstand its goal.  While I certainly can't speak on the developers' behalves, I can attest to the potential of this game's concepts.  Terra Invicta is primarily meant to be a game where politics, espionage, and warfare all mesh under the setting of a "plausible" alien infiltration of Earth.  There are certainly elements of all three in Terra Invicta, but then you have... ship construction?  Global Warming mechanics?  A bloated tech tree from hell?

These mechanics - while certainly interesting - detract from the essence of the game.  The game is a grand strategy, keyword grand.  You can't manage the individual economies of every nation on Earth while simultaneously committing espionage on your political opponents, all while fighting off aliens.  Well, you can, but then you run into the biggest problem of why doing too much in a single game ends up as a mess: time.

I played a single Terra Invicta run for about 65 hours and was not even a quarter of the way done with the game.  This is not a good thing; a game like this only holds the attention span of an individual for so long before they move onto something else for a while.  By spending so much time trying to connect so many different complex mechanics, each one fails to feel immersive, instead having a very gamey feel to it.

Other than that primary issue, there's also the assinine decision to blend turn-based and real-time onto the same strategic layer, making flexible management an utter nightmare.  Finally, there's a game direction change I'd make: Have nations be more hands-off, with subtle direction and especially allegiance being the player's main driving factor in the political sphere.  Unless you believe the world is run by "the cabal" or whatever, a gameplay loop that felt more like nudging nations rather than steering them outright would work wonders for immersion and interesting, replayable gameplay.

The best time I had in the game was in the early days of space warfare, where I basically partook in a pseudo-guerrilla war against the servants and protectorate, all while playing politics down on Earth, fighting a proxy war against the Academy for several African nations.  Overall, I can't recommend the game, but that's not to say there's no fun to be had here, or even that you will find the game as lackluster as I did. | A cool concept which breaks under the immense pressure of its many, MANY, parts. 

Everything I would want to critique can be summed by pointing out that less than 10 % of players have the 'Endgame' achievement, which basically gives you your faction victory condition. Only the victory CONDITION mind you, there's still 50 % of game to go at that point.

Like the transfer from Earth to Jupiter, this game is a SLOW burn. Blending real time and turn based while having to manage multiple layers of gameplay turns into a never ending cycle of interruption and slows things down tremendously by the midgame. Actually learning the game is obtuse and hard. You could learn everything about the already somewhat complex (and underexplained) earth layer and then be curbstomped by the additional amount of information you need to know to get a grasp on the economy, combat and strategy layer of space on top of it all. Naturally you need to manage both at the same time, yet one is half-turn based, as mentioned.

Ship building and the resulting space combat is as hard and obtuse as the strategic layers. Learning about the dozens of weapons, weapon types and multiple hundreds of techs makes preparing a fleet to fight with a chore. Its true that you are fighting an Alien adversary, and admitedly the initial horror of the unknown does have an impact, but his quickly turns into the ACTUAL horror of the unknown gameplay mechanics, as you realize that the game gives no guidance or help when it comes to fighting the Ayyys. 

Fission or Fusion? Laser or Phaser? Want your gun coiled or uncoiled? My ship just got zapped from 1000m, what exactly did I do wrong? Who the hell knows. Here's some councillor tasks to distribute before you go on youtube and learn what the multiple Excel spreadsheets worth of stats mean.

Terra Invicta is a rare case. The sum of its parts is less than what one would probably find if the spaghetti of mechanics and gameplay layers were to be untangled. Its an ambitious project that certainly has it's fans and enthusiasts, but I would argue this gets carried more by the premise of realistic sci-fi à la Expanse than the game design itself. 

Only recommended for the truely dedicated Sci-Fi lovers and people who love learning a lot of mechanics. But even then, just like 90 % of the playerbase before you, you will most likely run out of Δv before reaching the endgame anyway. | 建议出个以国家为主体派别为辅的模式，国家与国家之间谈判、合作、磨擦等。外星也拆开分为派别，这就可以国家身份与外星派别进行合作与其它派别对抗，望采纳！
 | It's hard to describe what kind of game this is. Obviously it's made by the people famous for making The Long War 1/2 mods for the newer x-com 1/2 games but it's a very far cry from being anything but thematically similar.
Some people also consider it to be two separate games but that's incorrect. It's a fusion of genres which interconnect in ways that allow longterm strategies to play over a *very* long normal speed campaign and still quite some time for an accelerated campaign.
It's basically a newtonian physics enabled solar system simulator with an added geopolitical game on earth. If you enjoy slowly building a shadow empire with one of seven different goals, depending on the faction, which eventually progresses to colonizing the solar system and building fleets of ships (which have battles using newtonian physics) then this game is for you. | Even in its current early access state this game is very close to being a masterpiece. If you like restarting the game. If you like being beaten to a pulp by hidden mechanics. If you dont mind spending 100+ hours on a single playthrough. But once you figure it out, this game provides you with a feeling of fulfilment I havent had in a while. Highly recommend even in its current state.

【给第九艺术的情书——一个中年玩家的博德之门3百小时旅程】
年近四十，上有老下有小的人是很难抽出整块时间坐在电脑前静静品味一个游戏，趁着这个春节，下定决心品尝这杯已经做好了多年的咖啡，于是力排众议顶住压力（感谢妻子的理解支持），在电脑前坐了一周indulging play，99小时40分通关了游戏，在深夜的屏幕前久久回味难以忘怀，震撼到无以复加，这注定是我人生难忘的精神之旅，也是我游戏编年史上最璀璨的坐标。

Larian在此呈现的，远非寻常意义上的电子游戏。
作为游戏，各种设计完美衔接，恰到好处；自由度高到令人发指，你可以做你自己；装备/等级/数据都是精心设计，兼顾了最大公约数；
作为音乐，Down by the river随河风飘扬成流动的叙事，I Want to Live在抉择时刻撕开灵魂，The Power见证胜利后紧握棱镜的双手，各类主题曲契合场景主题，已然挣脱媒介的桎梏，变成可以交互的交响诗，让我事后还反复专门聆听感慨；
作为剧本，这内容本身就是很精彩的小说，作者们绝对有撰写一部畅销魔幻小说的深厚功力。正义/邪恶，生存/死亡，杀戮/放生等人性和生命的主题引人哲思；如果去电影院是用2.5h欣赏了一部有深度的电影，那么在BG3，你是用100h+去体验有无奈有选择有善恶的跌宕魔幻人生。
我把游戏结束后在营地跟大家聊天的最后存档命名“Do not want to say Farewell”，一路走来，跟这堆朋友和战友同甘共苦，真的希望能一起继续生活下去，最后营地跟大家聊天穷尽选项，试图寻找更多的互动，特别是跟影心的七八次拥抱还留有数据的余温，舍不得说再见。但是Larian残忍又仁慈地让每个同行者带着伤痕继续前行——有人背负星辰远征，有人归于市井炊烟。这何尝不是最温柔的现实主义：所有相遇终究要归还给时光。
至此，我的龙与地下城故事已封存在剑湾的晚风中，有生之年，我还会再体验阿斯代伦和其它角色的一生。或许这正是CRPG的伟大之处：它允许我们在现实生活的夹缝里，体验无数个未曾活过的自己。

虽然也能看到一些对BG3批评改进的意见，但是瑕不掩瑜，个人认为有些地方确实可以再改进以方便玩家，有些意见却是因人而异而不能算作缺点和批评。
当你花了10-15h去学习这个游戏的机制和基本原理后跨过门槛，你真的无法想象Larian是如何创作出这样一部伟大作品的。如果这部作品无法被超越，是因为她确实太精湛也值得珍惜。如果被超越，那么游戏史上又多了另一颗明珠，也是我们的另一份礼物。
谢谢你，Larian。

A Love Letter to the Ninth Art – A Middle-Aged Player's 100-Hour Journey Through Baldur's Gate 3

As someone nearing forty, with both elderly parents and young children to care for, finding large chunks of time to sit in front of a computer and savor a game is no easy feat. This Spring Festival, I made up my mind to finally taste this cup of coffee that had been brewing for years. With the understanding and support of my wife (for which I am deeply grateful), I managed to carve out a week to indulge in uninterrupted play. After 99 hours and 40 minutes, I completed the game. Sitting in front of the screen late at night, I was left in awe, unable to shake the profound impact it had on me. This journey will undoubtedly remain one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life, a radiant milestone in my personal gaming history.

What Larian has created here is far from an ordinary video game.

As a game, every design element is seamlessly integrated, perfectly balanced. The freedom it offers is almost overwhelming—you can truly be yourself. The equipment, levels, and stats are meticulously crafted, catering to a broad spectrum of players.

As music, Down by the River drifts with the breeze, becoming a flowing narrative. I Want to Live tears at your soul during moments of decision, and The Power resonates as you grasp the prism in victory. Each theme song fits its scene so perfectly that it transcends the medium, transforming into an interactive symphonic poem that I found myself revisiting and reflecting on long after the game had ended.

As a novel, the content itself is a masterful piece of fantasy literature. The writers clearly possess the skill to craft a best-selling fantasy novel. Themes of justice versus evil, life versus death, and killing versus sparing provoke deep philosophical reflection. If watching a movie in a theater is like spending 2.5 hours appreciating a thought-provoking film, then Baldur's Gate 3 is like spending over 100 hours living a tumultuous, magical life filled with difficult choices and moral dilemmas.

I named my final save file in the camp, where I chatted with everyone before the end, "Do Not Want to Say Farewell." After journeying together, sharing both hardships and triumphs with these friends and comrades, I truly wished we could continue living together. I exhausted every dialogue option in the camp, searching for more interactions, especially with Shadowheart, whose seven or eight hugs still lingered with the warmth of data. I couldn’t bear to say goodbye. Yet, Larian, in their cruel yet merciful way, allowed each companion to move forward with their scars—some destined to carry the stars on their shoulders, others to return to the mundane life of hearth and home. This, perhaps, is the most tender form of realism: all encounters must eventually be returned to the passage of time.

Thus, my Dungeons & Dragons tale has been sealed in the evening breeze of the Sword Coast. In this lifetime, I will return to experience the lives of Astarion and other characters. Perhaps this is the greatness of CRPGs: they allow us, in the crevices of our real lives, to live countless versions of ourselves we never had the chance to be.

While there are some criticisms and suggestions for improvement regarding BG3, they are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless gem. Some aspects could indeed be tweaked for player convenience, while others are subjective preferences rather than flaws.

Once you’ve spent 10-15 hours learning the game’s mechanics and fundamental principles, crossing that threshold, you can’t help but marvel at how Larian managed to create such a masterpiece. If this work remains unrivaled, it’s because it is truly exquisite and deserves to be cherished. If it is ever surpassed, then another jewel will have been added to the annals of gaming history, another gift for us all.

Thank you, Larian. | The replayability of this game is insane, Larian did an amazing job giving us exactly what we wanted and maybe even a little more. This game has taken over my life and I love it so much, lol, and showing no signs of putting it down any time soon! | This is probably going to be one of the best games for the next decade, the voice acting is sublime and the writers seemed to have made deals with the devil in order to make such a good tale. 10/10 | I started playing this game a year and a few months after it was launched and immediately got into character creation which took me over an hour not to mention building my Dream Guardian. Since purchasing it at full price, I was weary to buy a game for 60 bucks, but it has been the best 60 bucks I've spent in a LONG time. 

The whole game itself doesn't hold your hand during the game, but it does help you build up your skills and learn how to play as you go which is great for those who haven't played CRPG turn based game before. I have basically played this nonstop since October to pass time and as you can see with my 527 hours on record, I absolutely LOVE this game. The options for responses and endings are endless. I'm thoroughly blown away with the voice acting and, yes, the mod options. There are many people who hate playing with mods, but to me it adds a lot to the game and enhances my game play experience making me want to play it more. I have done numerous campaigns and as of January 2025, I'm doing my 2nd durge campaign trying to play a somewhat evil character which is hard as I've cried from being evil to pixels haha. 

Overall, I think this game may be the best game I've ever played and I love how Larian and the VA's show their active participation in the community along with Larian giving us FREE updates and gives modders the toolkit. This company could've charged $100 or more for this game with the amount of work and thought put into it along with the (again) FREE updates, but they didn't. They have shown they care more for the player's experience and making a game that out beats other new games and certain *ahem developers AHEM Bethesda* by giving us a game that is completed at release (from what I've been told by other gamers who played this at release). I recommend this game to anyone who wants a rich, fulfilling game that doesn't have any extra catches outside the initial price. | I have played this game for 6 hours (2h on character creator), never played this type of game before.. can say I am impressed and enjoying it a lot.

18 hours in the game: I think that I'm addicted. The stories are surprising and wholesome. I feel like a hero in this game, living for the good of the people.

50 hours: I finally finished act 1. And oh boy did I turn from good to evil with every step I took. I didn't mean to be... How was I supposed to know that pulling the wrong lever, I'll be catapulting a gnome to space. That wasn't my fault.

80 hours: Yes! Give me your gold. All the shiny trinkets you have. Give me your soul and all the power you hold. Give me more... MORE!

100 hours: How dare you look down on me, thinking like you could ever defeat me?! Hit me with all you got, it will never be enough!

120 hours: ... *only screams echo in the darkness* ...

130 hours: *Muahahaha-*
You may call me the blood queen,
but your agenda is also driven by greed.
The battle you lost, your advisors lied.
Your heroes are dead, your city is mine.
No evil as dark or vengeance as red,
have never been seen as I took the kings head.
